title: Reading Data
text:
The readr package is the first package that we will learn about. This allows us to read in rectangular data like cvs files.
This is the typical way it goes when you have data located on your computer.

library(tidyverse)

dataset <- read_csv(file_path)

head(dataset)

Copy the file path from your computer and paste it in the function. One downside to this is you have to manually replace each backslash \ with a forwardslash /
Here is an example:

library(tidyverse)

bob <- read_csv("C:/Users/Bethany/Downloads/US_Population_200_Years.csv")

head(bob)

# A tibble: 6 × 7
   Rank City             Population  Year PopDate    Longitude Latitude
  <dbl> <chr>                 <dbl> <dbl> <chr>          <dbl>    <dbl>
1     1 New York, NY          33131  1790 06/01/1790     -73.9     40.7
2     2 Philadelphia, PA      44096  1790 06/01/1790     -75.1     40.0
3     3 Boston, MA            18320  1790 06/01/1790     -71.1     42.3
4     4 Charleston, SC        16359  1790 06/01/1790     -80.0     32.8
5     5 Baltimore, MD         13503  1790 06/01/1790     -76.6     39.3
6     7 Salem, MA              7921  1790 06/01/1790     -70.9     42.5

title: Reading Data
text:
Method 2: “Import Dataset” Button Option
Another option is to use the “Import Dataset” button in the environment pane of RStudio.


The data will now be in your environment.

title: Reading Data
section: Method 3: Getting data from a URL
text:
Method 3: Getting data from a URL
Often you get your data from online somewhere like GitHub or Kaggle. While there is the option to download the file, then read it from your computer locally, like we just did above, there’s also the option to read in data from a URL.
A benefit is that less memory is used on your computer. Another is that you can send your analysis with the data being read in from a URL, and others will be able to run the script without any data issues.
Below is an example.

library(tidyverse)

data1 <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/saundersg/Statistics-Notebook/master/Data/Rent.csv")

head(data1)

title: Reading Data
text:
Other Data File Formats
What if the dataset you have is not a csv? What if it’s an excel file or the often unused tsc?
Other options include:

read_excel() to read excel files like xls or xlsx
read_tsv() to read tsv files (tab separated files)
read_rds() to read RDS files (a data export option from SQLServer)

title: Reading Data
text:
Exceptions to the Norm
For most cases this is the way to read in data. There are some examples of variations.
Sometimes the column headers are not the top row of the data. In this scenario, use the option skip = 1 if there is one extra row above the headers.
Sometimes there are not column name at all and we’ll have to give them to the dataset. How can we do this?

title: Reading Data
text:
Writing Files
With readr, we can write data files.

write_csv(dataset_to_save, "file_name.csv")

how can I use the wiki tab on the github page? What is the proper usage of it?

Others: - commenting code - assignment operator vs equal sign - pipe operator %>% - filtering operators (==, %in%, |, &, !=) - c(vector) and list conversation
Use this for advance select statements: https://dplyr.tidyverse.org/reference/select.html
n_distinct(dat\(region) count(dat\)region) table(dat$region)
dat <- read_csv(“https://covid.ourworldindata.org/data/owid-covid-data.csv”) # object_size(dat) view(dat)
dat <- read_csv(“datasets/insurance.csv”)
n_distinct(dat\(region) count(dat\)region) table(dat$region)

title: Week 3
text:
Read in this dataset from this URL: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/saundersg/Statistics-Notebook/master/Data/Rent.csv
From this dataset:

select the Apartment, Gender, and Price columns
filter the Gender column to female apartments and remove NAs !is.na(Price)
find the average price of apartments


housing_data <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/saundersg/Statistics-Notebook/master/Data/Rent.csv")
head(housing_data)

# Starter Code
housing_data %>% 
    select() %>% 
    filter( , !is.na(Price)) %>% 
    summarise(mean())

title: Week 3
text:
Second Practice
The iris dataset is built into R.

Create a new column to tell if the Sepal.Length is bigger than or equal to 5
Sort the data by Petal.Length


head(iris)

# Starter Code
iris %>%
    mutate() %>% 
    arrange()

title: Welcome to Bootcamp
text: Welcome to Data Science Society’s R Bootcamp

title: Welcome to Bootcamp
text:
Course Outline:
The purpose of R Bootcamp is to be able to read, wrangle, and visualize data using R in RStudio. By the end of the course you will be able to contribute to a society project next semester.

Reading Data: readr package

navigating file systems
copy file paths
RStudio’s “Import Dataset” button, “From Text (readr)” option



Wrangling Data: dplyr/tidyr packages
Primary Focus: select, filter, mutate, groupby/summarise, and arrange.
Secondary Focus: joining, pivoting, case_when,
Other: drop_na(), replace_na(),


Visualizing Data: ggplot2 package

What kind of data these plot plot
code for each
histograms, boxplots, scatterplots, bar charts.

In Terms of Packages:

readr
dplyr/tidyr
ggplot

Others:

forcats (fct_reorder and working with factors)
stringr (working with text data)
lubridate (working with dates)
tibble (just the tibble() function)
purr (mappings, boring)

title: Welcome to Bootcamp
section: What kind of data are we using?
text:
What kind of data are we using?
We will mainly be using the _____ and the ____ datasets for practice.
What is data? Is it singular or plural?
What other types of data are there? Take this for example ____
We will be working with tabular data. Other data includes pictures, videos, and audio.
There are different types of data, we won’t get into the nitty-gritty parts of it, but there is structured, semi-structured, and ustructured data. We will be playing around with structured data (think excel files). Examples of the other types of data are pictures, video, and audio files.

readr: for data import
dplyr: for data manipulation
tidyr: for data tidying
ggplot2: for data visualisation
tibble: for tibbles, a modern re-imagining of data frames
stringr: for strings
forcats: for factors
purrr: for functional programming
+
lubridate: for dates

title: Wrangling Data
text:
Base R is the native tools that R has to deal with data. The syntax is outdated and better tools are available to use.
The syntax to work in Base R is very similar to native python syntax. The biggest downside is that it’s not possible to chain operations together like selecting columns and filtering data. You would to constantly assign and reassign variables which results in very messy and unreadable code.
If you use this, I will turn in my grave. Please don’t make your life more difficult, use the Tidyverse.
Base R is native to R; no additional installations are required.




The Tidyverse allows chainable actions like this:

new_dataset <- dataset %>% 
    select() %>%
    filter() %>% 
    mutate() %>% 
    group_by() %>% 
    summarise() %>%
    arrange()

Run this code in the console to download the tidyverse

install.packages("tidyverse")

In order to be able to use this package, put this code at the top of your R Script or RMD file

library(tidyverse)











df$column_name
df[[]]





df %>% select(column1, column2)











df$profit <- df$revenue - df$cost





df %>% mutate(profit = revenue - cost)












df[df$temperature > 45]





df %>% filter(temperature > 45)











I’m not sure how to do this in BaseR… and that’s okay





df %>% 
    group_by(city) %>% 
    summarise(Avg_House_Price = mean(house_price))











mtcars[order(mpg, -cyl),]





mtcars %>% arrange(mpg, desc(cyl))





Check out this page for more comparisons.
Filtering Data in Base R:

https://www.mitchcraver.com/2021/06/15/subsetting-and-filtering-a-data-frame-in-r/
https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/crunch/vignettes/filters.html

dat <- read_csv(“datasets/insurance.csv”)

title: Week 4: Grouping and Summarising
text:
Let’s learn about group_by() & summarise()
What if we want to learn:

the average BMI by gender
the total sum of charges by region in the US
min & max of children by  age

All of these are examples uses for group_by() and summarise() statements.

title: Week 4
text:
Exercise 1

dat <- read_csv("C:/Users/Bethany/Downloads/myblog/datasets/insurance.csv")

# n_distinct(dat$region)
# count(dat$region)
# table(dat$region) 


dat %>% 
    group_by(region) %>% 
    summarise(
        Count = n(), 
        Mean = mean(bmi), 
        Sum = sum(charges) %>% round()
        )

# A tibble: 4 × 4
  region    Count  Mean     Sum
  <chr>     <int> <dbl>   <dbl>
1 northeast   324  29.2 4343669
2 northwest   325  29.2 4035712
3 southeast   364  33.4 5363690
4 southwest   325  30.6 4012755



dat %>% 
    group_by(region, smoker) %>% 
    summarise(
        Count = n(), 
        Mean = mean(bmi), 
        Sum = sum(charges) %>% round()
        ) 

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'region'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.


# A tibble: 8 × 5
# Groups:   region [4]
  region    smoker Count  Mean     Sum
  <chr>     <chr>  <int> <dbl>   <dbl>
1 northeast no       257  29.3 2355542
2 northeast yes       67  28.6 1988127
3 northwest no       267  29.2 2284576
4 northwest yes       58  29.1 1751136
5 southeast no       273  33.4 2192795
6 southeast yes       91  33.1 3170895
7 southwest no       267  30.5 2141149
8 southwest yes       58  31.0 1871606

title: Week 4: Grouping and Summarising
text:
Exercise 1: Average BMI by Gender

dat %>% 
    group_by(sex) %>%
    summarise(Average_Age = mean(age))

# A tibble: 2 × 2
  sex    Average_Age
  <chr>        <dbl>
1 female        39.5
2 male          38.9

title: Week 4: Grouping and Summarising
text:
Exercise 2: Average BMI by Age

dat %>% 
    group_by(age) %>% 
    summarise(mean(bmi)) %>% 
    head() 

# A tibble: 6 × 2
    age `mean(bmi)`
  <dbl>       <dbl>
1    18        31.3
2    19        28.6
3    20        30.6
4    21        28.2
5    22        31.1
6    23        31.5

title: Week 4: Grouping and Summarising
section: Exercise 3: Sum of Charges by Region
text:
Exercise 3: Sum of Charges by Region
Use the code below to get you started. Find the sum of the charges by region.
Starter Code:

dat %>% 
    group_by(______) %>% 
    summarise(_____________ = ___(_______))

This is the correct output




region
Total_Charges




northeast
4343669


northwest
4035712


southeast
5363690


southwest
4012755




Attempt the code above then use this dropdown for help


Answer
dat %>% 
    group_by(region) %>% 
    summarise(Total_Charges = sum(charges))

title: Week 4: Grouping and Summarising
section: Exercise 4: Min & Max of Children by Age
text:
Exercise 4: Min & Max of Children by Age
Use the code below to get you started. Find the minimum and maximum amount of children by age.
Starter Code:

dat %>% 
    group_by(___) %>%
    summarise(
        Min = ___(),
        Max = ___()
        ) %>% 
    head()



Answer
dat %>% 
    group_by(age) %>%
    summarise(
        Min = min(children),
        Max = max(children)
        ) %>% 
    head()

title: Week 4: Grouping and Summarising
section: Exercise 4: Storm Dataset - Wind and Air Pressure
text:
Exercise 4: Storm Dataset - Wind and Air Pressure
This dataset is bult into R so you already have it. It is called storms. This is a new dataset so you may want to either view() it or use the head() method on it.
Find the average and standard deviation of the wind speed and air pressure by storm category.


Answer
storms %>% 
    group_by(category) %>% 
    summarise(
        mean(wind),
        sd(wind), 
        mean(pressure), 
        sd(pressure)
        ) %>% knitr::kable()


This is the correct output:




category
mean(wind)
sd(wind)
mean(pressure)
sd(pressure)

title: Week 4: Grouping and Summarising
text:
Exercise 5:
Find the mean, median, and standard deviation of wind speed by month.


Answer
storms %>% 
    group_by(month) %>% 
    summarise(
        Mean_Wind = mean(wind), 
        Median = median(wind), 
        St_Dev = sd(wind)
        ) %>% 
        knitr::kable()
